skills.name: Round decimals to the nearest whole number
Round numbers to an appropriate degree to estimate the answer to a calculation

explanations.A: Not quite. Is 8.3 closer to 8 or 9?
explanations.B: We have 8.3 rounding down to 8 and 12.9 rounding up to 13.
explanations.C: Not quite. Is 12.9 closer to 12 or 13?
explanations.D: Not quite. Think about which whole numbers these decimals are closest to.

explanations.A: Not quite. Is 9.1 closer to 9 or 10?
explanations.B: Not quite. Is 11.7 closer to 11 or 12?
explanations.C: We round 9.1 down to 9 and we round 11.7 up to 12.
explanations.D: Not quite. Think about which whole numbers these decimals are closest to.

explanations.A: The first number is approximately 10, but what is the approximate answer to the whole sum?
explanations.B: The second number is approximately 100, but what is the approximate answer to the whole sum?
explanations.D: Not quite. Just check that you have taken the decimal point into account when you are rounding the first number

explanations.A: Not quite. Just check that you have taken the decimal points into account when you are rounding
explanations.C: Not quite. Just check that you have taken the decimal points into account when you are rounding
explanations.D: Not quite. Just check that you have taken the decimal points into account when you are rounding

explanations.A: Not quite. 4000 ÷ 2 = 2000. BUT 193 is a very different number from 2. Remember to round to one significant figure when estimating.
explanations.B: Almost, just check the place value with your division
explanations.D: Almost, just check the place value with your division

explanations.A: Almost, just check the place value with your division
explanations.C: Almost, just check the place value with your division
explanations.D: I think you might have subtracted rather than divided

explanations.A: Not quite. If you look at the number after the 3, it is a 6. Does that tell us to round up or down?
explanations.B: Not quite. When we are estimating, we want to make the number really easy to work with. Only one of the digits should be non-zero.
explanations.C: Not quite. When we are estimating, we want to make the number really easy to work with. Only one of the digits should be non-zero.
explanations.D: We want the number to be roughly the right size but really easy to work with. Only one number should be non-zero. So rounding this to the nearest 1000, we have 4000

explanations.A: Not quite. If you look at the number after the 9, it is a 7. Does that tell us to round up or down?
explanations.B: We want the number to be roughly the right size but really easy to work with. Only one number should be non-zero. So rounding this to the nearest 10 000, we have 100 000

explanations.D: Not quite. When we are estimating, we want to make the number really easy to work with. Only one of the digits should be non-zero.

explanations.A: Not quite. When we are estimating, we want to make the number really easy to work with. Exactly one of the digits should be non-zero.
explanations.B: Not quite. If you look at the number after the 4, it is an 8. Does that tell us to round up or down?
explanations.C: We want the number to be roughly the right size but really easy to work with. Only one number should be non-zero. So rounding this to the nearest 1 decimal place, we have 0.5.
explanations.D: Not quite. When we are estimating, we want to make the number really easy to work with. Exactly one of the digits should be non-zero.
